title: 115_hr949
content: The "Children of Fallen Heroes Scholarship Act" is the short title of this legislation. It outlines the calculation of eligibility for the scholarship. Section 473(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include eligibility criteria for the "Children of Fallen Heroes Scholarship Act." This includes students whose parent or guardian died as a result of military service in Iraq or Afghanistan after September 11, 2001. The Children of Fallen Heroes Scholarship Act expands eligibility criteria for students whose parent or guardian died in the line of duty as a public safety officer. This includes adjustments to expected family contributions for qualifying students. The financial aid administrator must verify student eligibility, adjust the expected family contribution, and notify the Secretary of the adjustment. In cases of increased Federal Pell Grant amounts, special treatment applies. When there is an increased Federal Pell Grant amount, it will not affect the calculation of educational assistance benefits for public safety officers under the Public Safety Officers' Benefits program. The definition of a public safety officer includes those defined in the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 or fire police officers serving according to State or local law. The definition of a public safety officer includes individuals serving as scene security or directing traffic in response to emergencies or at planned events, who are not law enforcement officers, firefighters, chaplains, or rescue squad members. SEC. 3. CALCULATION OF PELL GRANT AMOUNT. Section 401(b)(2) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to specify the amount of the Federal Pell Grant for eligible students. In the case of students meeting certain requirements, the grant amount will be determined based on the last enacted appropriation Act for that award year. The Federal Pell Grant amount for eligible students is determined based on the last enacted appropriation Act for that award year. Students may receive an increase in funding if specified in advance in the appropriation Act for that year. The Federal Pell Grant amount for eligible students is determined based on the last enacted appropriation Act for that award year, with the possibility of an increase in funding specified in advance. Clauses (i) through (iii) of paragraph (7)(A) are relevant in this context. The Budgetary Effects of this Act will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The Act and its amendments will take effect on July 1, 2017.
